Trial_Design.evidence: We performed a retrospective cohort study considering 70 patients who underwent elective lobectomy, segmentectomy, or wedge resection surgery with a mini-thoracotomy approach or video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS).

Participants.evidence: 70 patients who underwent elective lobectomy, segmentectomy, or wedge resection surgery with a mini-thoracotomy approach or video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS).

Objective.evidence: The aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of dexamethasone as an analgesic adjuvant in minimally invasive thoracic surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcome was morphine consumption 24 h after surgery; secondary outcomes were pain control, measured as numeric rating scale (NRS), glycemic changes, PONV, and surgical wound infection.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 70 patients who underwent elective lobectomy, segmentectomy, or wedge resection surgery

Result_Outcome.evidence: There were no significant differences in morphine consumption at 24 h ( p = 0.09) and in postoperative pain scores.

Harms.evidence: No cases of surgical wound infections were detected, and the incidence of PONV was similar in the two groups.
